headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Northern Trust Corporation Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the call over to Director of Investor Relations, Mark Bette, for opening rema
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Northern Trust Corporation Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the call over to Director of Investor Relations, Mark Bette, for opening remarks and introductions. Please go ahead.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lisa. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to Northern Trust Corporation's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Joining me on our call this morning are Biff Bowman, our Chief Financial Officer; Jane Karpinski, our Controller; and Kelly M
componenttext:
Thank you, Lisa. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to Northern Trust Corporation's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Joining me on our call this morning are Biff Bowman, our Chief Financial Officer; Jane Karpinski, our Controller; and Kelly Moen from our Investor Relations team. 
For those of you who did not receive our third quarter earnings press release and Financial Trends Report via e-mail this morning, they are both available on our website at northerntrust.com. Also on our website, you will find our quarterly earnings review presentation, which we will use as a guide for today's call.
This October 19 call is being webcast live on northerntrust.com. The only authorized rebroadcast of this call is a replay that will be available on our website through November 16. Northern Trust disclaims any continuing accuracy of the information provided in this call after today.
In the current quarter, we elected to early adopt a new accounting standard issued earlier this year that made certain changes for stock-based compensation. One of the most significant changes requires that excess tax benefits and deficiencies be recorded as part of income tax expense rather than as part of additional paid-in capital. This change has been made for all periods in 2016. The impact resulted in a tax benefit of $6.4 million in the third quarter results and a benefit of $12.3 million on a year-to-date basis. Please see Page 11 of our earnings release for more information on the impact to our first and second quarter 2016 results. 
Now for our safe harbor statement. What we say during today's conference call may include forward-looking statements, which are Northern Trust's current estimates and expectations of future events or future results. Actual results, of course, could differ materially from those expressed or implied by these statements because the realization of those results is subject to many risks and uncertainties that are difficult to predict. I urge you to read our 2015 Annual Report on Form 10-K and other reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for detailed information about factors that could affect actual results.
[Operator Instructions] Thank you again for joining us today. Let me turn the call over to Biff Bowman.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. Let me join Mark in welcoming you to the Northern Trust Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Starting on Page 2 of our quarterly earnings review presentation. This morning, we reported third quarter net income of $258 milli
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone. Let me join Mark in welcoming you to the Northern Trust Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Starting on Page 2 of our quarterly earnings review presentation. This morning, we reported third quarter net income of $258 million. Earnings per share were $1.08 and our return on common equity was 11.7%. Our assets under custody increased 13% compared to 1 year ago and 6% sequentially. Our assets under management were up 7% compared to 1 year ago and up 4%, sequentially. 
The current quarter results include 2 items I wanted to highlight: First, the quarter included $5.4 million of impairment charges and loss on sales related to a nonstrategic loan and lease portfolio; second, we had a $3.5 million charge in connection with the settlement of our remaining securities lending litigation. All securities lending litigation stemming from the 2008 financial crisis is now resolved subject to final court approval. I will highlight these items again as we walk through our detailed results. 
A number of environmental factors impact our businesses as well as our clients. Before going through our results in detail, let me review how some of those factors unfolded during the third quarter. 
Equity markets performed well in the quarter. In U.S. market, the S&P 500 ended the quarter up 12.9% year-over-year and up 3.3%, sequentially. In international markets, the MSCI EAFE Index was up 1.6% year-over-year and up 5.4%, sequentially. Recall that some of our fees are based on lagged market values, and second quarter markets were not as strong as the third quarter. 
In bond markets. The Barclays U.S. Aggregate Index was higher for the year-over-year comparison but lower for the sequential comparison. Currency volatility, as measured by the G7 Index, was 2.6% higher than that the third quarter of last year but 8.4% lower, sequentially. Foreign exchange market volumes were down in the third quarter. 
As measured by 2 of the interbank brokers, volumes were down 14% to 17% year-over-year and down 9% to 11%, sequentially. You'll recall that currency volatility and client activity influenced our foreign exchange trading income. Currency rates influence the translation of non-U.S. currencies to the U.S. dollar and therefore, impact client assets and certain revenues and expenses. Dollar strength, particularly in the year-over-year comparison, tempered custody asset growth and related fee growth while benefiting expense growth. The most significant move was in the British pound, which ended the third quarter 14% lower than 1 year ago. 
Short-term interest rates were mixed during the quarter. U.S. short-term rates were higher than 1 year ago and also moved higher sequentially, most evident in the 3-month LIBOR which averaged 79 basis points during the quarter. In the U.K. however, short-term rates declined, driven by the Bank of England's August rate reduction of 25 basis points.
Let's move to Page 3 and review the financial highlights of the third quarter. Year-over-year, revenue increased 5%, with noninterest income up 3% and net interest income up 13%. Expenses increased 4%, which drove 1.3 points of positive operating leverage. The provision for credit losses was a credit of $3 million, reflecting ongoing improvement in credit quality. Net income was 10% higher year-over-year. In the sequential comparison, recall several items we reported to you last quarter. A pretax gain of $118.2 million on the sale of 1.1 million Class B Visa shares, a pretax charge of $46.5 million in connection with certain securities lending related litigation, a pretax loss of $21.6 million associated with our loan and lease portfolio, a pretax charge of $18.6 million relating to contractual modifications associated with existing C&IS asset servicing clients and a pretax charge of $17.5 million related severance and personnel-related costs. 
On an adjusted basis, excluding the second quarter items, revenue declined with noninterest income down 1% and net interest income slightly higher. Expenses were flat compared to the prior quarter, and net income was 1% higher, sequentially. Return on average common equity was at 11.7% for the quarter, up from the 10.9% reported 1 year ago but down from the 12.3% in the prior quarter. Adjusting for the previously mentioned second quarter items, the third quarter's return on average common equity was down from 11.9% in the prior quarter. Client assets under custody of $6.7 trillion increased 13% compared to 1 year ago and 6% on a sequential basis. In both the year-over-year and sequential comparisons, strong new business and favorable market impacts were partially offset by the currency translation impact of a stronger dollar. 
Assets under management were $946 billion, up 7% year-over-year and 4%, sequentially. Favorable market impacts and new business drove the growth in both comparisons. 
Let's look at the results in greater detail, starting with revenue on Page 4. Third quarter revenue on a fully taxable equivalent basis was approximately $1.2 billion, up 5% from last year but down 8%, sequentially. Adjusting for the second quarter items that I mentioned earlier, revenue was down 1%, sequentially. Trust, investment and other servicing fees represent the largest component of our revenue and were $788 million in the third quarter, up 5% year-over-year and up 1% from the prior quarter.
Lower money market mutual fund fee waivers were an important driver of the performance compared to last year. Fee waivers were essentially 0 in the third quarter compared to $28 million 1 year ago. Fee waivers were not a factor in the sequential comparison. 
Foreign exchange trading income was $54 million in the third quarter, down 15% year-over-year and down 17%, sequentially. Lower client volumes drove the year-over-year decline while the sequential decline reflected lower volatility as well as lower client volumes. 
Other noninterest income was $69 million in the third quarter, down 8% from last year and down 10% sequentially when adjusting for the second quarter items I mentioned previously. The current quarter's results include $4.7 million in revenue associated with the Aviate acquisition, which closed during the second quarter. The prior quarter's results included $2.6 million of Aviate associated revenue. Both the year-over-year and sequential declines were primarily driven by a $5.4 million loss associated with our lease portfolio, a $2.3 million loss associated with the mark-to-market of our Visa-related swaps as well as lower brokerage and credit-related fees. 
Net interest income, which I will discuss in more detail later, was $310 million in the third quarter, increasing 13% year-over-year and up 1%, sequentially. 
Let's look at the components of our trust and investment fees on Page 5. For our Corporate & Institutional Services business, fees totaled $451 million in the third quarter, up 5% year-over-year and 1% on a sequential basis. Custody and fund administration fees, the largest component of C&IS fees, were $299 million, up 2% both on a year-over-year and sequential basis. Assets under custody for C&IS clients were $6.2 trillion at quarter end, up 13% year-over-year and up 6%, sequentially. These results primarily reflect new business and favorable markets, partially offset by the unfavorable currency exchange rates. Recall that lagged market values factor into the quarter's fees with both quarter lag and month lag markets impacting our C&IS custody and fund administration fees. 
Investment management fees in C&IS of $94 million in the third quarter were up 14% year-over-year and flat, sequentially. The year-over-year growth was driven in large part by lower money market mutual fund fee waivers. As was the case last quarter, fee waivers and [ph] C&IS were essentially 0 during the third quarter compared to $12 million, 1 year ago. 
Assets under management for C&IS clients were $704 billion, up 6% year-over-year and 5%, sequentially. 
Securities lending fees were $23 million in the third quarter, 14% lower than the prior quarter, but up 17% year-over-year. The sequential quarter decline reflects the typical seasonal pattern with the international dividend season driving wider spreads in the second quarter of each year. The year-over-year increase was driven by increased spreads, primarily relating to the widening of the spread between 3-month LIBOR and Fed funds. 
Securities lending collateral was $114 billion at quarter end and averaged $113 billion across the quarter. Average collateral levels decreased 7% year-over-year and were down 3%, sequentially. The decline in loan volumes compared to the prior year was across most asset classes. Security lending activity has been impacted by the regulatory landscape as actions have been taken by agent lenders and borrowers to calibrate capital usage. 
Other fees and [ph] C&IS were $34 million in the third quarter, up 1% year-over-year and up 4% sequentially, reflecting higher fees from investment risk and analytical services, benefit payments and other ancillary services. 
Moving to our Wealth Management business. Trust, investment and other servicing fees were $338 million in the third quarter, up 6% year-over-year and 2%, sequentially. Within Wealth Management, the Global Family Office business had strong performance with fees increasing 12% year-over-year and 2% sequentially due to lower money market mutual fund fee waivers compared to one year ago as well as favorable markets and new business. 
Performance within the regions also benefited from lower [Audio Gap] [ph] fee waivers compared to last year as well as favorable markets and new business. Money market mutual fund fee waivers and [ph] Wealth Management were essentially 0 in the current quarter, which was equal to the prior quarter and down $15 million year-over-year. 
Assets under management for Wealth Management clients were $242 billion at quarter end, up 8% year-over-year and 4%, sequentially.
Moving to Page 6. Net interest income was $310 million in the third quarter, up 13% year-over-year. Earning assets averaged $108 billion in the third quarter, up 7% versus last year, driven by higher level of deposits and short-term borrowings. Demand deposits, which average $26 billion, increased 6% year-over-year, and non-U.S. office interest-bearing deposits, which averaged $51 billion, were up 3% year-over-year. Loan balances averaged $34 billion in the third quarter, up 2% compared to 1 year ago. The net interest margin was 1.14% in the third quarter and was up 6 basis points from a year ago. The improvement in the net interest margin compared to the prior year primarily reflects a higher yield on earning assets as short-term interest rates rose following the Fed's move in December. 
On a sequential quarter basis, excluding the previously mentioned $2.7 million impairment in the prior quarter, net interest income was up slightly and average earning assets were up 1% while the net interest margin was down 3 basis points, sequentially. While our net interest margin saw a [ph] benefit due to higher U.S. short-term interest rates, mainly the 1 month LIBOR, this was offset by the Bank of England rate cut of 25 basis points in August and the change in our overall earning asset mix. Day count also had a slight detrimental impact on our net interest margin in the third quarter. 
Premium amortization was $20 million in the third quarter, up from $14 million 1 year ago but flat with the second quarter. 
Turning to Page 7. Expenses were $843 million in the third quarter, up 4% year-over-year and down 9%, sequentially. Excluding the second quarter items I mentioned earlier, expenses were essentially flat on a sequential basis. The current quarter's expenses included $6.6 million in costs associated with the Aviate acquisition compared to $3.4 million in the prior quarter. This quarter's expenses also included the $3.5 million charge relating to the settlement of certain securities lending related litigation as I mentioned in the beginning of my comments. 
Now let's go through the components of expense. My comments going forward will exclude the second quarter items I mentioned earlier, totaling $82.6 million. Compensation expense of $382 million increased 6% year-over-year, primarily reflecting staff growth and higher performance-based compensation, partially offset by the favorable translation impact of changes in currency rates. Staff levels increased approximately 5% year-over-year. The growth in staff was all attributable to lower costs locations, which include India, Manila, Limerick and Tempe, Arizona. On a sequential basis, compensation expense increased 1%, driven by the impact of current quarter severance charges, staff growth and higher performance-based incentive accruals. Recall that the annual base pay adjustments were deferred from earlier in the year, and were made effective October 1, which we expect will result in a $7 million lift to compensation expense in the fourth quarter. 
Employee benefit expense of $73 million was up 5% year-over-year, primarily reflecting higher medical costs, partially offset by lower pension expense. On a sequential quarter basis, employee benefit expense was up 4%, driven by higher medical costs. 
Outside services expense of $158 million was flat compared to the prior year as higher technical services, Aviate-related expense and subcustodian costs were offset by lower consulting related spend and third-party adviser fees year-over-year. On a sequential quarter basis, outside service expense was also flat as higher levels of technical services, legal and subcustodian costs were offset by lower levels of consulting spend. 
Equipment & Software expense of $115 million was up 1% from one year ago, but down 3%, sequentially. The year-over-year growth was due to higher software-related expense. The sequential decline was driven by software amortization and computer maintenance and rental-related costs. Spending in support of our strategy continues as we invest to support clients, improve employee efficiency and meet Regulatory and Compliance requirements. Other operating expense of $71 million increased 9% year-over-year, primarily related to the previously mentioned $3.5 million securities lending litigation settlement and higher FDIC costs of $3 million associated with the newly implemented assessment surcharge on banks with consolidated assets of $10 billion or more. 
Sequentially, other operating expense declined 3% on an adjusted basis. Declines associated with asset-servicing amortized cost, the timing of charitable contributions and other miscellaneous expenses more than offset increases from the security lending litigation settlement and a $2 million sequential increase in FDIC expense.
Our loan loss provision was a credit of $3 million in the third quarter. This compares to a provision credit of $3 million in the prior quarter and a credit of $10 million in the prior year. The credit provision in the current quarter was primarily driven by a reduction in outstanding loans and improved credit quality in the residential real estate portfolio, partially offset by an increase in the specific reserve requirement for the commercial portfolio. Nonperforming assets of $181 million were up from $166 million in the prior quarter, but down from the $207 million 1 year ago. Loan quality remains very strong with the ratio of nonperforming loans to total loans equal to only 52 basis points at quarter end.
Turning to Page 8. A key focus has been on sustainably enhancing profitability and returns. This slide reflects the progress we have made in recent years to improve the expense-to-fees ratio, pretax margin and ultimately, our return on equity. The ratio of expenses to trust and investment fees is a particularly important measure of our progress as it addresses what we can most directly control. Reducing this measure from where it was previously, as high as 131% in 2011, to the levels we see today is a key contributor to the improvement on our return on equity. As you can see on this page, our performance in the current quarter has continued to drive the ratio lower and is now at 107%. This metric remains an important barometer of our progress, and we remain committed to lowering it on a sustainable basis going forward through continuing to win new business to drive fee growth and driving productivity within our expense base through our ongoing initiatives focused on location, strategy, procurement and technology.
Turning to page 9. Our capital ratios remained solid with common equity Tier 1 ratios of 11.8% and 11.2%, respectively, calculated on a transition basis for both advanced and standardized. On a fully phased-in basis, our common [Audio Gap] [ph] tier 1 capital ratio under the advance approach would be approximately 11.6% [ph], and under the standardized approach would be approximately 11%. All of these ratios are well above the fully phased-in requirement of 7%, which includes the capital conservation buffer. The supplementary leverage ratio at the corporation was 6.6%, and at the bank, was 5.9%, both of which exceed the 3% requirement, which will be applicable to Northern Trust in 2018.
With respect to the liquidity coverage ratio, Northern Trust is above the 90% minimum requirement effective as of January 2016 and is also above the 100% minimum requirement that will become effective on January 1, 2017. As Northern Trust progresses through fully phased-in Basel III implementation, there could be additional enhancements to our models and further guidance from the regulators on the implementation of the final rule, which could change the calculation of our regulatory ratios under the final Basel III rules. 
During the third quarter, Northern Trust issued $500 million in perpetual preferred stock and an initial fixed dividend rate of 4.6 through October 1, 2020 16 [ph] -- 2026. Fixed-rate dividends for this new issuance are expected to be paid on a semiannual basis, with the first dividend anticipated to be declared at the January 2017 Board of Directors meeting and paid April 1, 2017. Given the early August issuance, the initial preferred dividend payment will cover 8 months and therefore, is expected to equal $14.9 million in the first quarter of 2017. Going forward, these fixed-rate dividends are expected to be paid every other quarter in the amount of $11.5 million.
Beginning October 1, 2026, dividends on this issuance are expected to be paid quarterly at a floating rate equal to 3-month LIBOR plus 3.202%. In the third quarter, we repurchased 950,000 shares of common stock at a cost of $65 million. During the quarter, we increased our quarterly cash dividend by 6% to $0.38 per common share. 
In closing, the global macroeconomic environment continue to produce a difficult operating environment in the third quarter of 2016. Low and even negative interest rates around the globe, post Brexit uncertainty, election uncertainty and debate over Central Bank actions characterize the quarter. Despite that challenging backdrop, Northern Trust produced solid financial results, growing our earnings per share 13% year-over-year. We also produced 1.3 points of positive operating leverage and importantly, drove our expense-to-fee ratio to 107%. Our return on equity of 11.7% represents an 80 basis point improvement over one year ago.
Our Wealth Management business grew total revenue 7% year-over-year with fees up 6%. This business had a pretax margin of 41%. New business success in our highest network categories remain strong. Our C&IS business generated 6% revenue growth and 5% fee growth. Our new business in the quarter helped us grow organically and was exemplified with wins such as [indiscernible] life and the expansion of relationships with existing clients such as the New Zealand Superannuation Fund.
In our Asset Management business, we celebrated the fifth anniversary of our ETF franchise per shares [ph]. Since its launch 5 years ago, the suite of ETF's has grown from 4 funds to 24 and attracted more than $10 billion in assets. During the quarter, we once again had positive flows that outstripped industry averages.
Lastly, in the quarter, we successfully executed the issuance of 500 million in preferred stock, taking advantage of attractive market pricing and creating capital flexibility for the firm going forward. 
Thank you, again, for participating in Northern Trust third quarter earnings conference call today. Mark and I would like -- would be happy to answer your questions. Lisa, please open the line.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Ashley Serrao with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Ashley Serrao with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to dig a little deeper into NIM dynamics. First, I just wanted to confirm if the decline in yields within the Federal Reserve and other Central Bank deposit bucket was due to the Bank of England rate cut. And then just an update on the usage
componenttext: I just wanted to dig a little deeper into NIM dynamics. First, I just wanted to confirm if the decline in yields within the Federal Reserve and other Central Bank deposit bucket was due to the Bank of England rate cut. And then just an update on the usage of short-term borrowings and how you're managing the current reinvestment environment with the potential rate hike on the horizon.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So the first part of your question around the Central Bank deposit yield was largely driven by the Bank of England's move, cutting the rates from 50 to 25 basis points, so you are accurate that, that was a primary driver of that decline. As we think
componenttext: Sure. So the first part of your question around the Central Bank deposit yield was largely driven by the Bank of England's move, cutting the rates from 50 to 25 basis points, so you are accurate that, that was a primary driver of that decline. As we think about using short-term borrowings that you described, what you would see on our balance sheet in short-term borrowings or funding sources, we can, from time to time, use federal home loan borrowings. They have an advantage, if you will, around our liquidity needs so we use them to manage our balance sheet liquidity from time to time. And they help, if you will, with LCR compliance and other issues. So that's how we think about the short-term borrowings that, in any given period, we can utilize for those types of purposes.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just a follow-up on the last part. How are you thinking about the current reinvestment environment with the potential rate hike on the horizon?
componenttext: And just a follow-up on the last part. How are you thinking about the current reinvestment environment with the potential rate hike on the horizon?

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. As we think about the -- a potential rate rise, as you know, our portfolio typically remain short in duration. We would expect that if a rate rise were to happen in November or, more likely, December, based on market ratification, that we would benef
componenttext: Yes. As we think about the -- a potential rate rise, as you know, our portfolio typically remain short in duration. We would expect that if a rate rise were to happen in November or, more likely, December, based on market ratification, that we would benefit from that. What is important to remember is, how do the markets react in advance of that? How well-telegraphed is that rate increase? So if it's unexpected, we would anticipate seeing the benefit to come perhaps in the first quarter or second quarter of next year. If the markets anticipate that, well, then we could see some of that benefit in fourth quarter. And then the last component that I would highlight here is, it also then matters greatly as to how the deposit pricing reacts to that anticipated rate hike. As you know, in the last rate hike, the deposit data remained low. We will wait to observe how it unfolds this time.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Alex Blostein with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Alex Blostein with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just staying on the NIM and NII discussion for a second. Just a point of clarification. I think last quarter, you guys had a fairly elevated amount of premium amortization running through the numbers. It looks like the yield on the guidance didn't really
componenttext: Just staying on the NIM and NII discussion for a second. Just a point of clarification. I think last quarter, you guys had a fairly elevated amount of premium amortization running through the numbers. It looks like the yield on the guidance didn't really move. So was this quarter somewhat elevated as well, and again, kind of created a little bit of a bigger drag on the NIM? Or kind of 114 basis points is a fairly decent run rate for us to start thinking about 4Q?

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we did see comparable levels of premium amortization in the second and third quarters. In absolute amounts, in both the second and third quarter, our premium amortization was approximately $20 million in both quarters. In 2015, our premium amortiz
componenttext: Yes. So we did see comparable levels of premium amortization in the second and third quarters. In absolute amounts, in both the second and third quarter, our premium amortization was approximately $20 million in both quarters. In 2015, our premium amortization in the third quarter was $14 million. So we did not see the seasonal decline that we had in previous cycles. In fact, in the year before that, it was almost $13 million. So we did not see the premium amortization seasonal decline that we've typically experienced in the third quarter. Traditionally in the fourth quarter and first quarter, we see our lowest levels of premium amortization. But again, in this third quarter, we saw slightly elevated premium amortization and less benefit from the seasonal decline.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. Okay. So all else equal, if freights don't really change. We should think about the normal kind of seasonal patterns for Q4 and 1Q?
componenttext: Got you. Okay. So all else equal, if freights don't really change. We should think about the normal kind of seasonal patterns for Q4 and 1Q?

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. All things being equal, right. Refinanced levels, market dynamics, housing markets et cetera. But all things, we should see -- we typically see seasonal decline in the fourth quarter.
componenttext: Yes. All things being equal, right. Refinanced levels, market dynamics, housing markets et cetera. But all things, we should see -- we typically see seasonal decline in the fourth quarter.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, fair enough. And then my second question was around the balance sheet as well. But think about the longer dynamic you guys have obviously, had a little bit of decline sequentially, probably due to the charge. But bigger picture. The bucket is kind of
componenttext: Yes, fair enough. And then my second question was around the balance sheet as well. But think about the longer dynamic you guys have obviously, had a little bit of decline sequentially, probably due to the charge. But bigger picture. The bucket is kind of range down to these levels for the last couple of quarters after seeing a couple of years, a really nice loan growth. How should we think about that on the forward basis? I know part of your capital return plan I think was contemplating the fact that you guys are growing and loan growth could be one of the components of why the capital return dynamic was quite lower than we had expected. So maybe kind of tie together for us as we think about the loan growth outlook.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me -- you're right, our loan growth year-over-year was 2%. But I think we have to decompose that a little bit. First of all, residential real estate loans declined 12% year-over-year. And that's strategically an initiative that we've been on as
componenttext: Sure. Let me -- you're right, our loan growth year-over-year was 2%. But I think we have to decompose that a little bit. First of all, residential real estate loans declined 12% year-over-year. And that's strategically an initiative that we've been on as we look at our wholesale designation and really, our upmarket practice and our Wealth Management best-in-class. So that's a conscious decision on the residential real estate. So that has been a drag on that loan growth. The second thing, as we look year-over-year at loan growth, our C&I loans are actually up 6%. Commercial real estate's up 11% and private client lending is up 17%. So we actually have seen loan growth in the areas that we've targeted and I think that is important. Sequentially, if you look at that, the residential real estate continued it's decline. C&I did decline. And I think we're seeing that across the industry from what I've seen in C&IS -- C&I loans. Commercial real estate was 1% and private client was up 3%, sequentially. So we had the right mix of that. As it relates to RWA growth or use of capital and capital returns. What we're disciplined around is not using our capital to put on whether it's loans or any other risk-weighted asset growth items that aren't generating the right level of returns. So we won't just use it to grow the balance sheet for nonstrategic RWA growth. And in this case, as I highlighted for you in the case of residential real estate for us, the slowing there is something that we're targeting strategically.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ken Houston with Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ken Houston with Jefferies.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Biff, this quarter, you had really good just core business growth metrics, AUM, AUC, AUA. Of course, the market was up and international was up a little bit more. But I was wondering if you could break them out and understanding, was there notable good ne
componenttext: Biff, this quarter, you had really good just core business growth metrics, AUM, AUC, AUA. Of course, the market was up and international was up a little bit more. But I was wondering if you could break them out and understanding, was there notable good net new business this quarter? Was it more about mix and where the dollars came from? Just thinking about kind of underlying organic growth and wins.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So when we decompose those growth rates, which were strong, approximately 50% was driven by the market levels that you described. But 50% was really driven by what I would say, positive flows and/or new business. So at the core, we saw good strong new bus
componenttext: So when we decompose those growth rates, which were strong, approximately 50% was driven by the market levels that you described. But 50% was really driven by what I would say, positive flows and/or new business. So at the core, we saw good strong new business across the franchise across in wealth, asset management and C&IS. We saw very, very good strong growth. And I would say generally across the globe, so whether it was in Asia Pacific region and in Australia, or in our European region where we had substantial new wins or even here in North America in our C&IS business. And in Wealth, largely across our geographies, we continue to see I think accelerated success in some of our large market investments like New York City that's growing double or triple the overall Wealth management averages to date. So I think it was a broad base set of successes that really drove that, not just a market driven beat, like I said about 50% was from new business and/or flows.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, got it. Great. And separately, can you just talk a little bit about the market sensitive revenues? Obviously, we saw the market environment for FX be kind of weak. And in the summer quarters, can you help us understand? Do you think it was more driv
componenttext: Okay, got it. Great. And separately, can you just talk a little bit about the market sensitive revenues? Obviously, we saw the market environment for FX be kind of weak. And in the summer quarters, can you help us understand? Do you think it was more driven by low volume or low volatility? And what about the mix of channel, if it was core custody on the electronic piece that you've been building?

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we're still heavily linked to both volatility and volume. You're right. We've absolutely tried to invest in our EAFE platforms for FX trading, but we're still directionally moving in lockstep with both volatility and volume. I would say volatility
componenttext: Yes. So we're still heavily linked to both volatility and volume. You're right. We've absolutely tried to invest in our EAFE platforms for FX trading, but we're still directionally moving in lockstep with both volatility and volume. I would say volatility would be mixed whether year-over-year or sequentially. We had negative sequential volatility, but positive year-over-year. It also matters, Ken, in -- whether it's emerging market currencies or its G7 currencies and the volatility between the 2. So most of our FX though, the vast majority of our FX is really driven by our core custody business. It's in relation to supporting the asset managers that are supporting our clients or our clients needs. There's not a proprietary trading element to this. It's just in support of that. So it will be and move lockstep with volumes and volatility in general.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Brian Bedell with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Brian Bedell with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe just 2 and just going to the fourth quarter, I think Biff, you mentioned a $7 million increase in comp, linked quarter. But if you can just touch on seasonality trends in the fourth quarter. Typically, there's usually growth in outside services and
componenttext: Maybe just 2 and just going to the fourth quarter, I think Biff, you mentioned a $7 million increase in comp, linked quarter. But if you can just touch on seasonality trends in the fourth quarter. Typically, there's usually growth in outside services and equipment and software expense. Just wanted to see if that still seems to be the general trend. And also the tax rate in the fourth quarter with the accounting change.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Let me break out outside services first for you. Real quickly, our outside service category, which totaled about $158 million in the third quarter. Approximately 1/3 of that is directly related to what I would say our market activities. It's items s
componenttext: Okay. Let me break out outside services first for you. Real quickly, our outside service category, which totaled about $158 million in the third quarter. Approximately 1/3 of that is directly related to what I would say our market activities. It's items such as subcustodian expense, third-party adviser fees, brokerage, clearing expense, et cetera. So it will move as the markets move in that quarter. And you would stay linked to that. About half is what I would say is what we call technical services, and it's generally linked to business activity. It's things like market data, use of market data, systems and processing, client customization work, but it's generally linked, if you will, to the directional revenue of the firm and that -- the third part, probably the part that we're talking about here is about 20%. And that's the most discretionary. That's things like consulting spent. We would -- in the third quarter, we saw a meaningful decline in our consulting spend. We're going to work hard to maintain that discipline in the fourth quarter as well around that component of outside services. And then I think you also had a question on the tax rate as well.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, just the Equipment & Software expense as well on the seasonal bit line.
componenttext: Yes, just the Equipment & Software expense as well on the seasonal bit line.

componenttextpreview: The Equipment & Software. If you look at past the seasonal trends, those have a small increase or a modest increase typically in the fourth quarter.
componenttext: The Equipment & Software. If you look at past the seasonal trends, those have a small increase or a modest increase typically in the fourth quarter.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Usually, Ken, that would be with the software amortization continuing trends.
componenttext: Usually, Ken, that would be with the software amortization continuing trends.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's actually [indiscernible]
componenttext: Okay. That's actually [indiscernible]

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: The tax rate. So that is dependent on A, the amount of equity that would either vest or be exercised and the value of the stock at the point of that exercise. That's how that tax rate works. If the price of the equity exercise is higher than that the poin
componenttext: The tax rate. So that is dependent on A, the amount of equity that would either vest or be exercised and the value of the stock at the point of that exercise. That's how that tax rate works. If the price of the equity exercise is higher than that the point it was granted, it will be a favorable tax benefit. And if it's not, then it will -- I can't predict how that will play out in the fourth quarter. But as you know, this is a practice that we've had with that 1 1 17 [ph] either way.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Great. And then maybe just longer-term question on investment in the business and technology that you mentioned a little bit about that as well. But think about the asset servicing business and with some of the competitors are doing in the industry
componenttext: Right. Great. And then maybe just longer-term question on investment in the business and technology that you mentioned a little bit about that as well. But think about the asset servicing business and with some of the competitors are doing in the industry with project Beacon and Bank of New York with some digital efforts. How do you feel your asset servicing businesses positioned from a technological perspective? And then there -- if the volume were investment required in that? And are you able to leverage the Omnium platform across your franchise more effectively?

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we -- we've made substantial technological advancements and investments. As our industry and our space in our industry as you describe. Wee rarel are looking at a series of initiatives to invest in that we think well A, first enhance our clients e
componenttext: Yes. So we -- we've made substantial technological advancements and investments. As our industry and our space in our industry as you describe. Wee rarel are looking at a series of initiatives to invest in that we think well A, first enhance our clients experience in terms of the mobile applications or the interface they may have when they come into the firm. But also drive efficiency inside the firm. And that could be efforts around robotics or other efficiencies inside the firm. One of the advantages we have, we believe, is that our organic growth strategy over time has allowed us to have largely single platforms for all of the areas we need to process on. And so our ability to deploy capital is pretty efficient. And so we think that our spend, which we do highlight, I think, total capital and technological expense is about $2.4 billion over a 3-year cycle. So we think that's enough to keep us competitive and on peer or above our competition.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mike Mayo with CLSA.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mike Mayo with CLSA.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you discuss Europe a little bit? With the restructuring of some global banks, are you seeing market share potential? Do see potential to pursue deals in Europe? Are you looking to add in Europe? Or are you repositioning in Europe? If we can net [indis
componenttext: Can you discuss Europe a little bit? With the restructuring of some global banks, are you seeing market share potential? Do see potential to pursue deals in Europe? Are you looking to add in Europe? Or are you repositioning in Europe? If we can net [indiscernible] with the European banks and Brexit and everything else.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, good question. We certainly do see a lot of movement in Europe right now as many of the large globally systemic important banks are revisiting their business models. We've had tremendous success in Europe, particularly in our GFS business where we've
componenttext: Yes, good question. We certainly do see a lot of movement in Europe right now as many of the large globally systemic important banks are revisiting their business models. We've had tremendous success in Europe, particularly in our GFS business where we've grown substantially over the last decade. And we are always opened and have understanding of what business we're interested in. As we've stated before, our approach to any of those opportunities is always first around a client capability. Second about really filling a geographic gap, and then third, I think a technological gap. But I think the market right now is experiencing some white water. And we stand ready to have dialogues and those that fit our strategic needs. Well certainly, have dialogues. If I go on just briefly. With Brexit, a little bit linked to your question, but while there's still a great deal of uncertainty on the U.K. exit, we had formulated plans to establish a full subsidiary in the EU. We have meaningful presence in Ireland and Luxembourg and several other locations today. And we will evaluate all of those from where the optimal location is for us that we are actively engaging in that planning right now.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So does Brexit cost you money then? Or it's not that big a deal because euro elsewhere in Europe?
componenttext: So does Brexit cost you money then? Or it's not that big a deal because euro elsewhere in Europe?

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we have physical presence in many of those locations and talent in those locations. But I am sure there would be some element of cost to look at incorporation and all the legal work that we would have to do with that. We think that's at a very manageab
componenttext: So we have physical presence in many of those locations and talent in those locations. But I am sure there would be some element of cost to look at incorporation and all the legal work that we would have to do with that. We think that's at a very manageable level though relative to our overall financial position.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Glenn Schorr with Evercore.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Glenn Schorr with Evercore.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Forgive if this is a little repetitive. But on the decision on taking down the payout ratio, part of it was for agencies as part of it was to have a better positioning in your -- with your capital ratios. And part of it was for the investment growth. Some
componenttext: Forgive if this is a little repetitive. But on the decision on taking down the payout ratio, part of it was for agencies as part of it was to have a better positioning in your -- with your capital ratios. And part of it was for the investment growth. Some of the stuff we talked out here, but I'm curious to revisit. Where are we going to see the benefits of that decision? Will it be a simple as higher capital ratio? But should we see higher growth rates relative to peers? I mean, some of this technology, some of it is actual growth in the business.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that we need to demonstrate that, that it's driving higher growth rates than our peers and higher returns on our capital over time because the businesses we're choosing to invest in in that. And as we said on previous calls, if we don't see t
componenttext: Yes, I think that we need to demonstrate that, that it's driving higher growth rates than our peers and higher returns on our capital over time because the businesses we're choosing to invest in in that. And as we said on previous calls, if we don't see the opportunity for that growth, we have an annual opportunity to revisit our capital distribution strategy. And we do with our board and our regulators. We revisit that. When we did that process 3, 6 months ago really in the planning phases of that, we had certain growth trajectories build into our planning and modeling. And we continue to execute on those. If those don't manifest, then we will revisit that plan in the 2017 submission cycle. What I said earlier though, I'd reiterate is, there is a discipline about not just using that retained capital if you will, or any risk-weighted assets. So any loan or any other risk-weighted asset. It is a disciplined approach for those that we think can generate superior returns over time.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Fair enough. Just one follow-up. In inside Wealth Management, curious, you have these differentiated growth rates across the regions and especially in Global Family. I wonder how much of that relates to the money market fee waiver we capture and how much
componenttext: Fair enough. Just one follow-up. In inside Wealth Management, curious, you have these differentiated growth rates across the regions and especially in Global Family. I wonder how much of that relates to the money market fee waiver we capture and how much of that is just pure business mix at the different type of customer.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in the Global Family Office, money market fee waivers is a meaningful portion of that driver. As you might imagine, those are large, very high network families that often look more like an institutional type investor and may have had large cash balance
componenttext: So in the Global Family Office, money market fee waivers is a meaningful portion of that driver. As you might imagine, those are large, very high network families that often look more like an institutional type investor and may have had large cash balances in their portfolio. So fee waivers for them was a meaningful driver. Across the other regions, I'd say that's a better mix of fee waiver benefit and actual new business and flows.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Geoffrey Elliott with Autonomous Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Geoffrey Elliott with Autonomous Research.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you give us updates on the Department of  Labor, fiduciary rule as you work through the impact? How is it in fact, shaping up relative to your initial expectations?
componenttext: Could you give us updates on the Department of  Labor, fiduciary rule as you work through the impact? How is it in fact, shaping up relative to your initial expectations?

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. We are continuing, if you will, to evaluate the impact of the fiduciary rule. And we've spent a lot of time and energy, as you might have suspected, and that evaluation and continue. Together with outside counsel and consulting experts on the DOL fi
componenttext: Sure. We are continuing, if you will, to evaluate the impact of the fiduciary rule. And we've spent a lot of time and energy, as you might have suspected, and that evaluation and continue. Together with outside counsel and consulting experts on the DOL fiduciary standards. At this time, we expect that any changes to our business model and product offerings will be limited and the costs associated with the design implementation and ongoing monitoring of compliance will be moderate. We continue to wait for further guidance along with our industry and further clarifications, I think we anticipate perhaps some Q&A and other items to come out to give us further guidance. But at this point in time, as I said, we think that it will be a moderate impact and limited business model changes is what we're anticipating.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just to check on one of the previous questions, Biff, I understood what you were saying correctly. When you asked about dislocation among European banks, the impact of that, kind of sounds like that's an area you're focusing on when you're thinki
componenttext: And then just to check on one of the previous questions, Biff, I understood what you were saying correctly. When you asked about dislocation among European banks, the impact of that, kind of sounds like that's an area you're focusing on when you're thinking about M&A opportunities. Did I understand that, right?

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I would say that we focus on 3 areas when we think about where we can grow. And in your case, you're asking inorganically. The first is it filling a client need or gap? Is there a product gap? The second is there is a geography or a regional gap in ou
componenttext: No. I would say that we focus on 3 areas when we think about where we can grow. And in your case, you're asking inorganically. The first is it filling a client need or gap? Is there a product gap? The second is there is a geography or a regional gap in our array of capabilities? And third, is there a technological or talent gap in those? That's where we start. I think the question was phrased, there's European institutions that are contemplating their own organizational structure. So many of those may have a capability or a geography or a technological or talent gap where we have a need. So now, that may manifest itself. I don't think there's an extraordinary amount of focus on Europe versus any other region in the world. But right now, there's probably a lot of institutions that are contemplating their own business structures now. And we stand ready to look at any opportunities that fit the first 3 criteria laid out for you.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Brian Kleinhanzl with KBW.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Brian Kleinhanzl with KBW.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: One quick question on the move in the pound Sterling this quarter. I mean, that have a big impact on the revenues overall? Or could you quantify that for us?
componenttext: One quick question on the move in the pound Sterling this quarter. I mean, that have a big impact on the revenues overall? Or could you quantify that for us?

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hi, Brian. It's Mark. The -- when you look at the P&L, it's important to remember that we do have a natural hedge where we have both revenue and expense in denominated currencies. And then to the extent that there's an exposure, we hedge it. As far as the
componenttext: Hi, Brian. It's Mark. The -- when you look at the P&L, it's important to remember that we do have a natural hedge where we have both revenue and expense in denominated currencies. And then to the extent that there's an exposure, we hedge it. As far as the growth rates go, when you look at it on a year-over-year basis, the trustee impact would probably be in the area of revenue impacted the most by about 1 to 1.5 percentage points. And then on the expense side as well, you're looking at about a 1% to 1.5% benefit year-over-year on the currencies. And then sequentially, the results of some impact there as well in both trust fees and expense were 1% or so lower due to currency exchange rates.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then I heard you say that you have $3.6 million of expenses related to the Aviate acquisition. Was just merger-related charges? Or was that the increase in run rate that you were saying was $3.6 million? Sorry for the clarification.
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then I heard you say that you have $3.6 million of expenses related to the Aviate acquisition. Was just merger-related charges? Or was that the increase in run rate that you were saying was $3.6 million? Sorry for the clarification.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Mark again. That was a $3.6 million impact in the quarter. What I would say is that, that would include the quarter's expense were $6.6 million. Last quarter was $3.4 million. So in the $6.6 million, there's a modest amount of still integration expen
componenttext: It's Mark again. That was a $3.6 million impact in the quarter. What I would say is that, that would include the quarter's expense were $6.6 million. Last quarter was $3.4 million. So in the $6.6 million, there's a modest amount of still integration expense. But we are calling that out just for the fact that the second quarter was kind of an abbreviated quarter because the acquisition closed in May.

componenttext: Looking at the Wealth Management business. The assets under custody and assets under management both this quarter exceeded, the mover in the S&P 500. But if I look back over the last few years since you're in 2013, the growth in that assets under custody and assets under management has been about 7.5% to 9%, respectively when the S&P has been up about 17%. So just curious about how you can explain that difference in the Wealth Management business with assets under custody and other management underperforming moves in the equity market.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I can start David, if you want, just by talking a little bit about the allocation amount and if Biff has anything to add. Currently with Wealth Management, when we look at AUM, about 47% are on equities as of the end of the quarter. 29% in fixed inco
componenttext: Yes. I can start David, if you want, just by talking a little bit about the allocation amount and if Biff has anything to add. Currently with Wealth Management, when we look at AUM, about 47% are on equities as of the end of the quarter. 29% in fixed income and 34% in cash -- or 24% in cash and other. So certainly, how the assets are allocated would be part of what the driver is there.

componenttext: I don't -- I think just the macro trends. And this is a little off the question. But just the macro trends we've seen in Wealth Management be the migration from active to passive and others have had some imputed impact on the business as well as quite frankly, just flows. Meaning as people have used their principles to live on in others, that's had a drag on our assets under management, in particular. The assets under custody and our Wealth business are driven a little bit more by our GFO business -- our Global Family Office which where you tend to have larger pools, more than the traditional wealth business.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Most of my questions have been asked. So maybe just on money market, mutual fund reform. Have you seen any change in behavior whether it's deposit flows or in the money market space? In terms of your corporate or retail customers? Just trying to get a sen
componenttext: Most of my questions have been asked. So maybe just on money market, mutual fund reform. Have you seen any change in behavior whether it's deposit flows or in the money market space? In terms of your corporate or retail customers? Just trying to get a sense of how that's playing out.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Across the industry, really, over $1 trillion in AUM moved into government funds. And what we've seen in our funds is no different. You'll be able to see the asset levels on each of our funds on our funds websites. But overall, we have seen a migrati
componenttext: Yes. Across the industry, really, over $1 trillion in AUM moved into government funds. And what we've seen in our funds is no different. You'll be able to see the asset levels on each of our funds on our funds websites. But overall, we have seen a migration from prime and/or other fund of such ilk into government and/or treasury funds meaningfully. Notably, for us, is that we didn't see our total AUM drop in that, just the mix moved dramatically into government-related funds. In fact, I think we're actually up $15 billion since -- in cash AUM since 2014 -- the summer of 2014. So we've seen that asset class grow. But the mix clearly shifted into government. What we didn't see was any meaningful migration onto the balance sheet. So we did see that shifts from prime and/or other gated or various funds in the treasury and government funds, but not on the balance sheet.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So that's it's interesting. It really just stayed within the money market complex. It didn't shift to deposits.
componenttext: So that's it's interesting. It really just stayed within the money market complex. It didn't shift to deposits.

componenttext: Wanted to ask you a little bit about the premium amortization in a sense that prepayments kicked off over the last couple of quarters. Is that real Tom? Is there any lag? So as we expect that from a seasonal standpoint going down, but also just from prepayment speeds slowing, I would expect that some of that premium amortization would also be kind of drift lower because of that as well.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So traditionally, that's what we've observed into the fourth quarter. And as you rightfully pointed out, there's a series of factors other than just seasonality. It's generally market conditions, interest rates and a series of other factors. Our normal pa
componenttext: So traditionally, that's what we've observed into the fourth quarter. And as you rightfully pointed out, there's a series of factors other than just seasonality. It's generally market conditions, interest rates and a series of other factors. Our normal pattern has been to see that in the fourth quarter come off. The $20 million of premium amortization that you saw in the third quarter, as I said, was elevated over the previous year 2015's third quarter by about $6 million. So we saw some modest decline in '15 from Q2 to Q3. This year, we saw basically flat between the 2. And in both of those years, we saw meaningful declines from Q3 to Q4.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: The piece that I'm also trying to get at, it was initially this year, you came in expanding your duration or lengthening duration using what looked to be a little bit more in the mortgage-backed securities. Then, you had the premium that got hit because o
componenttext: The piece that I'm also trying to get at, it was initially this year, you came in expanding your duration or lengthening duration using what looked to be a little bit more in the mortgage-backed securities. Then, you had the premium that got hit because of the amortization in prepayments. Have you slowed down on your utilization of your balance sheet capacity to put on? Has this kind of spooked you a little bit at all? I just don't see the same progression that we saw earlier this year, in utilizing that capacity to increase the yield on your securities portfolio.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So with the mortgage-backed that you're talking about has increased, I would say, very modestly as a percent as you describe it. I would not say it was because of being spooked by premium amortization. Because as you know, that plays itself out over
componenttext: Yes. So with the mortgage-backed that you're talking about has increased, I would say, very modestly as a percent as you describe it. I would not say it was because of being spooked by premium amortization. Because as you know, that plays itself out over time. So that isn't the decision criteria. I think the duration positions that we make is just part of our asset liability process and our view on future rate movements. So I wouldn't say that first of all, it hasn't moved materially in size it's a portfolio. And secondly, it certainly wasn't because of in your words, spooked, because of the premium amortization.

componenttext: The last thing I was going to ask you is part of your capital decisioning was the fact that competitors were under pressure from regulatory kind of capital requirements and liquidity requirements, which was helping push some incremental deposits, some balance sheets your way. Do you feel like that is starting to settle as we're kind of seeing some of the others have less pressure us kind of up accomplish a lot of movement that they needed to over the last year?

I think we retained and remain committed to the discipline we had in bringing those deposits on in the first place, which is looking at opportunity of any substantial size and determining what the return dynamics are opiate. We may be seeing a little bit fewer of those though.

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I got a question on your noninterest expense as a percentage of trust and investment fees on your Slide 8. Do you guys have any longer-term targeted goal of where you think that can get there? And as part of that question. Obviously, you have had success
componenttext: I got a question on your noninterest expense as a percentage of trust and investment fees on your Slide 8. Do you guys have any longer-term targeted goal of where you think that can get there? And as part of that question. Obviously, you have had success taking in from 120 down to 107 from 12 to where we are today. These strategies used to do that. Was it primarily cutting expenses rather than seeing revenue growth? Or was it more revenue growth? And how do you see that playing out to get to an ultimate target in the next 2 or 3 years?

headline: Northern Trust Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We would -- we've not say that a public target for that ratio other than to say that we continue to try to drive bit lower. So we've not seen anything other than were committed to driving it lower over time. The way we think about it, Gerard, is that
componenttext: Yes. We would -- we've not say that a public target for that ratio other than to say that we continue to try to drive bit lower. So we've not seen anything other than were committed to driving it lower over time. The way we think about it, Gerard, is that our most reliable income source is our trust investment servicing fees. And if we continue to have that cover more and more of our operating expenses, it allows for some of the other profitability line items like foreign exchange, net interest income to truly flow straight into the bottom line. In terms of how we get after it. It's really is a dual effort. It really is both a revenue and the expense line. On the revenue line, we think about that as the organic growth in their is controllable by us. So the ability to move new business, retain clients, is 100% inside of our capabilities and efforts around new products capabilities, services that we can bring to our client base is important. And so we focus on the organic growth in our -- on the fee side. On the expense side. We've highlighted some of those initiatives to you. Probably most prominent over the last 3 to 5 years in driving that ratio has been our ability to locate our people in the right cost type locations. A great example is, in this quarter, net, our net headcount grew only in what we deem to be Tier 2 and Tier 3 locations. There are other initiatives. We've talk about procurement, we've talked about technology saves where it's cloud-based work or storage-based work et cetera. But we really get after them, the expense side where we do believe there are still levers inside the expense base that we continue to pull. A combination of those, we think can continue to drive that ratio lower. It is more difficult as we eliminate some of the lower hanging fruit.
